Shawi Dictionary Schema

This TEI customization fits the needs of the SHAWI-Project while conforming with the baseline schema of all dictionaries created at the ACDH-CH.

Part 1: Encoder Documentation

1. Basic Dictionary Structure

The dictionaries covered by this schema are encoded according to the Guidelines of the Text Encoding Initiative (P5). They are conceptualised as a specific type of text and are therefore encoded with <text> elements. Each dictionary starts with a <teiHeader> element which contains the metadata of the dictionary.

The lexicographic data are placed in typed <div> elements. Thus, our TEI dictionaries basically look like this:

<TEIÂ version="5.0" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Â <teiHeader> ... </teiHeader> Â <text> Â Â <body> Â Â Â <divÂ type="entries"> Â Â Â Â <entry>...</entry> Â Â Â Â <entry>...</entry> Â Â Â Â <entry>...</entry> Â Â Â </div> Â Â </body> Â </text> </TEI>

The <body> of a dictionary which conforms to this specification may not only contain a flat series of entries but also examples (which are encoded as <cit>/<quote> constructs). The rationale behind keeping example sentences outside the entries is to be able to reuse them in different parts of the dictionary (See below: Examples and Creating examples).

2. Part 2: Formal Specification

2.1. Elements

2.1.1. <TEI>

<TEI> (TEI document) contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resource class. Multiple <TEI> elements may be combined within a <TEI> (or <teiCorpus>) element. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
Moduletextstructure
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
lex-0
versionspecifies the version number of the TEI Guidelines against which this document is valid.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.version
Note

Major editions of the Guidelines have long been informally referred to by a name made up of the letter P (for Proposal) followed by a digit. The current release is one of the many releases of the fifth major edition of the Guidelines, known as P5. This attribute may be used to associate a TEI document with a specific release of the P5 Guidelines, in the absence of a more precise association provided by the source attribute on the associated <schemaSpec>.

Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
header: teiHeader
textstructure: TEI text
Note

This element is required. It is customary to specify the TEI namespace http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0 on it, for example: <TEI version="4.4.0" xml:lang="it" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">.

Example
<TEIÂ version="3.3.0" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Â <teiHeader> Â Â <fileDesc> Â Â Â <titleStmt> Â Â Â Â <title>The shortest TEI Document Imaginable</title> Â Â Â </titleStmt> Â Â Â <publicationStmt> Â Â Â Â <p>First published as part of TEI P2, this is the P5 Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  version using a namespace.</p> Â Â Â </publicationStmt> Â Â Â <sourceDesc> Â Â Â Â <p>No source: this is an original work.</p> Â Â Â </sourceDesc> Â Â </fileDesc> Â </teiHeader> Â <text> Â Â <body> Â Â Â <p>This is about the shortest TEI document imaginable.</p> Â Â </body> Â </text> </TEI>
Example
<TEIÂ version="2.9.1" xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> Â <teiHeader> Â Â <fileDesc> Â Â Â <titleStmt> Â Â Â Â <title>A TEI Document containing four page images </title> Â Â Â </titleStmt> Â Â Â <publicationStmt> Â Â Â Â <p>Unpublished demonstration file.</p> Â Â Â </publicationStmt> Â Â Â <sourceDesc> Â Â Â Â <p>No source: this is an original work.</p> Â Â Â </sourceDesc> Â Â </fileDesc> Â </teiHeader> Â <facsimile> Â Â <graphicÂ url="page1.png"/> Â Â <graphicÂ url="page2.png"/> Â Â <graphicÂ url="page3.png"/> Â Â <graphicÂ url="page4.png"/> Â </facsimile> </TEI>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ prefix="tei" Â uri="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"/> <sch:nsÂ prefix="xs" Â uri="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"/>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ prefix="rng" Â uri="http://relaxng.org/ns/structure/1.0"/> <sch:nsÂ prefix="rna" Â uri="http://relaxng.org/ns/compatibility/annotations/1.0"/>
Schematron
<sch:nsÂ prefix="sch" Â uri="http://purl.oclc.org/dsdl/schematron"/> <sch:nsÂ prefix="sch1x" Â uri="http://www.ascc.net/xml/schematron"/>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="teiHeader"/>
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.resource"
Â Â Â Â Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="TEI"Â minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â </sequence>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="TEI"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â </sequence>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element TEI
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type { "lex-0" },
   attribute version { text }?,
   ( teiHeader, ( ( model.resource+, TEI* ) | TEI+ ) )
}â

2.1.2. <abbr>

<abbr> (abbreviation) contains an abbreviation of any sort. [3.6.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions]
Modulecore
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
type(type) allows the encoder to classify the abbreviation according to some convenient typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Sample values include:
suspension
(suspension) the abbreviation provides the first letter(s) of the word or phrase, omitting the remainder.
contraction
(contraction) the abbreviation omits some letter(s) in the middle.
brevigraph
the abbreviation comprises a special symbol or mark.
superscription
(superscription) the abbreviation includes writing above the line.
acronym
(acronym) the abbreviation comprises the initial letters of the words of a phrase.
title
(title) the abbreviation is for a title of address (Dr, Ms, Mr, â¦)
organization
(organization) the abbreviation is for the name of an organization.
geographic
(geographic) the abbreviation is for a geographic name.
Note

The type attribute is provided for the sake of those who wish to classify abbreviations at their point of occurrence; this may be useful in some circumstances, though usually the same abbreviation will have the same type in all occurrences. As the sample values make clear, abbreviations may be classified by the method used to construct them, the method of writing them, or the referent of the term abbreviated; the typology used is up to the encoder and should be carefully planned to meet the needs of the expected use. For a typology of Middle English abbreviations, see 6.2.

Member of
model.pPart.editorial
Contained by
core: abbr author bibl biblScope citedRange date editor gloss head item name note p pubPlace publisher quote resp term
header: authority change distributor edition extent licence principal rendition tagUsage
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
May contain
core: abbr cit date gloss name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

If abbreviations are expanded silently, this practice should be documented in the <editorialDecl>, either with a <normalization> element or a <p>.

Example
<choice> Â <expan>North Atlantic Treaty Organization</expan> Â <abbrÂ cert="low">NorATO</abbr> Â <abbrÂ cert="high">NATO</abbr> Â <abbrÂ cert="high"Â xml:lang="fr">OTAN</abbr> </choice>
Example
<choice> Â <abbr>SPQR</abbr> Â <expan>senatus populusque romanorum</expan> </choice>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element abbr
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type { text }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}â

2.1.3. <affiliation>

<affiliation> (affiliation) contains an informal description of a person's present or past affiliation with some organization, for example an employer or sponsor. [15.2.2. The Participant Description]
Modulenamesdates
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.editLike
    • @evidence
    • @instant
  • att.datable
    • @period
    • att.datable.w3c
      • @when
      • @notBefore
      • @notAfter
      • @from
      • @to
    • att.datable.iso
      • @when-iso
      • @notBefore-iso
      • @notAfter-iso
      • @from-iso
      • @to-iso
    • att.datable.custom
      • @when-custom
      • @notBefore-custom
      • @notAfter-custom
      • @from-custom
      • @to-custom
      • @datingPoint
      • @datingMethod
  • att.naming
    • @role
    • @nymRef
    • att.canonical
      • @key
      • @ref
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Sample values include:
sponsor
recommend
discredit
pledged
calendarindicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs.
Deprecatedwill be removed on 2024-11-11
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@calendar]"> <sch:assertÂ test="string-length( normalize-space(.) ) gt 0"> @calendar indicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs, but this <sch:name/> element has no textual content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Member of
model.addressLike
Contained by
core: abbr author bibl biblScope citedRange date editor gloss head item name note p pubPlace publisher quote resp term
header: authority change distributor edition extent licence principal rendition tagUsage
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
May contain
core: abbr cit date gloss name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

If included, the name of an organization may be tagged using either the <name> element as above, or the more specific <orgName> element.

Example
<affiliation>Junior project officer for the US <nameÂ type="org">National Endowment for Â Â  the Humanities</name> </affiliation>
ExampleThis example indicates that the person was affiliated with the Australian Journalists Association at some point between the dates listed.
<affiliationÂ notAfter="1960-01-01" Â notBefore="1957-02-28">Paid up member of the <orgName>Australian Journalists Association</orgName> </affiliation>
ExampleThis example indicates that the person was affiliated with Mount Holyoke College throughout the entire span of the date range listed.
<affiliationÂ from="1902-01-01" Â to="1906-01-01">Was an assistant professor at Mount Holyoke College.</affiliation>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element affiliation
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.editLike.attributes,
   att.datable.attributes,
   att.naming.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type { text }?,
   attribute calendar { list { + } }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}â

2.1.4. <analytic>

<analytic> (analytic level) contains bibliographic elements describing an item (e.g. an article or poem) published within a monograph or journal and not as an independent publication. [3.12.2.1. Analytic, Monographic, and Series Levels]
Modulecore
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
Contained by
core: biblStruct
May contain
core: author date editor ref respStmt title
header: availability idno
Note

May contain titles and statements of responsibility (author, editor, or other), in any order.

The <analytic> element may only occur within a <biblStruct>, where its use is mandatory for the description of an analytic level bibliographic item.

Example
<biblStruct> Â <analytic> Â Â <author>Chesnutt, David</author> Â Â <title>Historical Editions in the States</title> Â </analytic> Â <monogr> Â Â <titleÂ level="j">Computers and the Humanities</title> Â Â <imprint> Â Â Â <dateÂ when="1991-12">(December, 1991):</date> Â Â </imprint> Â Â <biblScope>25.6</biblScope> Â Â <biblScope>377â380</biblScope> Â </monogr> </biblStruct>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="author"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="editor"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="respStmt"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="title"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.ptrLike"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="date"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="textLang"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="availability"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration

{
   att.global.attributes,
   (
      author
    |Â editor
    |Â respStmt
    |Â title

2.1.6. <author>

<author> (author) in a bibliographic reference, contains the name(s) of an author, personal or corporate, of a work; for example in the same form as that provided by a recognized bibliographic name authority. [3.12.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement]
Modulecore
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.naming
    • @role
    • @nymRef
    • att.canonical
      • @key
      • @ref
  • att.datable
    • @period
    • att.datable.w3c
      • @when
      • @notBefore
      • @notAfter
      • @from
      • @to
    • att.datable.iso
      • @when-iso
      • @notBefore-iso
      • @notAfter-iso
      • @from-iso
      • @to-iso
    • att.datable.custom
      • @when-custom
      • @notBefore-custom
      • @notAfter-custom
      • @from-custom
      • @to-custom
      • @datingPoint
      • @datingMethod
calendarindicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs.
Deprecatedwill be removed on 2024-11-11
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@calendar]"> <sch:assertÂ test="string-length( normalize-space(.) ) gt 0"> @calendar indicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs, but this <sch:name/> element has no textual content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Member of
model.respLike
Contained by
core: analytic bibl monogr
header: editionStmt titleStmt
May contain
core: abbr cit date gloss name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

Particularly where cataloguing is likely to be based on the content of the header, it is advisable to use a generally recognized name authority file to supply the content for this element. The attributes key or ref may also be used to reference canonical information about the author(s) intended from any appropriate authority, such as a library catalogue or online resource.

In the case of a broadcast, use this element for the name of the company or network responsible for making the broadcast.

Where an author is unknown or unspecified, this element may contain text such as Unknown or Anonymous. When the appropriate TEI modules are in use, it may also contain detailed tagging of the names used for people, organizations or places, in particular where multiple names are given.

Example
<author>British Broadcasting Corporation</author> <author>La Fayette, Marie Madeleine Pioche de la Vergne, comtesse de (1634â1693)</author> <author>Anonymous</author> <author>Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation</author> <author> Â <persName>Beaumont, Francis</persName> and <persName>John Fletcher</persName> </author> <author> Â <orgNameÂ key="BBC">British Broadcasting Â Â  Corporation</orgName>: Radio 3 Network </author>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element author
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.naming.attributes,
   att.datable.attributes,
   attribute calendar { list { + } }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}â

2.1.8. <availability>

<availability> (availability) supplies information about the availability of a text, for example any restrictions on its use or distribution, its copyright status, any licence applying to it, etc. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Moduleheader
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.declarable
    • @default
status(status) supplies a code identifying the current availability of the text.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
free
(free) the text is freely available.
unknown
(unknown) the status of the text is unknown.
restricted
(restricted) the text is not freely available.
Member of
model.biblPart
Contained by
core: analytic bibl monogr
header: publicationStmt
May contain
core: p
header: licence
Note

A consistent format should be adopted

Example
<availabilityÂ status="restricted"> Â <p>Available for academic research purposes only.</p> </availability> <availabilityÂ status="free"> Â <p>In the public domain</p> </availability> <availabilityÂ status="restricted"> Â <p>Available under licence from the publishers.</p> </availability>
Example
<availability> Â <licenceÂ target="http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT"> Â Â <p>The MIT License Â Â Â Â  applies to this document.</p> Â Â <p>Copyright (C) 2011 by The University of Victoria</p> Â Â <p>Permission is hereby granted, free of charge, to any person obtaining a copy Â Â Â Â  of this software and associated documentation files (the "Software"), to deal Â Â Â Â  in the Software without restriction, including without limitation the rights Â Â Â Â  to use, copy, modify, merge, publish, distribute, sublicense, and/or sell Â Â Â Â  copies of the Software, and to permit persons to whom the Software is Â Â Â Â  furnished to do so, subject to the following conditions:</p> Â Â <p>The above copyright notice and this permission notice shall be included in Â Â Â Â  all copies or substantial portions of the Software.</p> Â Â <p>THE SOFTWARE IS PROVIDED "AS IS", WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR Â Â Â Â  IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO THE WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY, Â Â Â Â  FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE AND NONINFRINGEMENT. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE Â Â Â Â  AUTHORS OR COPYRIGHT HOLDERS BE LIABLE FOR ANY CLAIM, DAMAGES OR OTHER Â Â Â Â  LIABILITY, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, TORT OR OTHERWISE, ARISING FROM, Â Â Â Â  OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE SOFTWARE OR THE USE OR OTHER DEALINGS IN Â Â Â Â  THE SOFTWARE.</p> Â </licence> </availability>

Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"

2.1.10. <biblScope>

<biblScope> (scope of bibliographic reference) defines the scope of a bibliographic reference, for example as a list of page numbers, or a named subdivision of a larger work. [3.12.2.5. Scopes and Ranges in Bibliographic Citations]

Member of
model.imprintPart
Contained by
core: bibl imprint monogr
header: seriesStmt
May contain
core: abbr cit date gloss name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

When a single page is being cited, use the from and to attributes with an identical value. When no clear endpoint is provided, the from attribute may be used without to; for example a citation such as âp. 3ffâ might be encoded <biblScope from="3">p. 3ff</biblScope>.

It is now considered good practice to supply this element as a sibling (rather than a child) of <imprint>, since it supplies information which does not constitute part of the imprint.

Example
<biblScope>pp 12â34</biblScope> <biblScopeÂ unit="page"Â from="12"Â to="34"/> <biblScopeÂ unit="volume">II</biblScope> <biblScopeÂ unit="page">12</biblScope>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    â

   att.citing.attributes,
   macro.phraseSeq
}â

</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element catDesc
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.canonical.attributes,
   term,
   gloss?
}â

2.1.15. <change>

<change> (change) documents a change or set of changes made during the production of a source document, or during the revision of an electronic file. [2.6. The Revision Description 2.4.1. Creation 11.7. Identifying Changes and Revisions]

calendarindicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs.
Deprecatedwill be removed on 2024-11-11
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@calendar]"> <sch:assertÂ test="string-length( normalize-space(.) ) gt 0"> @calendar indicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs, but this <sch:name/> element has no textual content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
target(target) points to one or more elements that belong to this change.
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Contained by
header: listChange revisionDesc
May contain
core: abbr bibl biblStruct cit date gloss list listBibl name note p quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

The who attribute may be used to point to any other element, but will typically specify a <respStmt> or <person> element elsewhere in the header, identifying the person responsible for the change and their role in making it.

It is recommended that changes be recorded with the most recent first. The status attribute may be used to indicate the status of a document following the change documented.

Example
<titleStmt> Â <title> ... </title> Â <editorÂ xml:id="LDB">Lou Burnard</editor> Â <respStmtÂ xml:id="BZ"> Â Â <resp>copy editing</resp> Â Â <name>Brett Zamir</name> Â </respStmt> </titleStmt> <!-- ... --> <revisionDescÂ status="published"> Â <changeÂ who="#BZ"Â when="2008-02-02" Â Â status="public">Finished chapter 23</change> Â <changeÂ who="#BZ"Â when="2008-01-02" Â Â status="draft">Finished chapter 2</change> Â <changeÂ n="P2.2"Â when="1991-12-21" Â Â who="#LDB">Added examples to section 3</change> Â <changeÂ when="1991-11-11"Â who="#MSM">Deleted chapter 10</change> </revisionDesc>
Example
<profileDesc> Â <creation> Â Â <listChange> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="DRAFT1">First draft in pencil</change> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="DRAFT2" Â Â Â Â notBefore="1880-12-09">First revision, mostly Â Â Â Â Â Â  using green ink</change> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="DRAFT3" Â Â Â Â notBefore="1881-02-13">Final corrections as Â Â Â Â Â Â  supplied to printer.</change> Â Â </listChange> Â </creation> </profileDesc>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
    â

element change

2.1.16. <cit>

<cit> (cited quotation) contains a quotation from some other document, together with a bibliographic reference to its source. In a dictionary it may contain an example text with at least one occurrence of the word form, used in the sense being described, or a translation of the headword, or an example. [3.3.3. Quotation 4.3.1. Grouped Texts 9.3.5.1. Examples]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
Modulecore
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
type
StatusRequired
Legal values are:
example
A dictionary example. Ideally, examples should consist in complete sentences. Examples should be concise, but can also contain several sentences. If dialogical models are involved, sentences are to be separated by a dash.
translation
A translation.
translationEquivalent
A translation equivalent.
etymon
An etymon.
subtype
StatusOptional
Legal values are:
proverb
Proverbs are a subtype of example.
verbatim
TODO description missing
scientificName
TODO descripion missing
Member of
model.entryPart.top model.quoteLike model.sensePart
Contained by
core: abbr author biblScope cit citedRange editor gloss head item name note p pubPlace publisher quote ref term title
dictionaries: def entry etym form gram lang orth pron sense xr
header: change distributor edition extent licence rendition tagUsage
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
textstructure: div
May contain
core: bibl cit gloss note quote
dictionaries: form usg
iso-fs: fs
Example
<cit> Â <quote>and the breath of the whale is frequently attended with such an insupportable smell, Â Â  as to bring on disorder of the brain.</quote> Â <bibl>Ulloa's South America</bibl> </cit>
Example
<entry> Â <form> Â Â <orth>horrifier</orth> Â </form> Â <citÂ type="translation"Â xml:lang="en"> Â Â <quote>to horrify</quote> Â </cit> Â <citÂ type="example"> Â Â <quote>elle Ã©tait horrifiÃ©e par la dÃ©pense</quote> Â Â <citÂ type="translation"Â xml:lang="en"> Â Â Â <quote>she was horrified at the expense.</quote> Â Â </cit> Â </cit> </entry>
Example
<citÂ type="example"> Â <quoteÂ xml:lang="mix">Ka'an yu tsa'a Pedro.</quote> Â <mediaÂ url="soundfiles-gen:S_speak_1s_on_behalf_of_Pedro_01_02_03_TS.wav" Â Â mimeType="audio/wav"/> Â <citÂ type="translation"> Â Â <quoteÂ xml:lang="en">I'm speaking on behalf of Pedro.</quote> Â </cit> Â <citÂ type="translation"> Â Â <quoteÂ xml:lang="es">Estoy hablando de parte de Pedro.</quote> Â </cit> </cit>
Schematronassert correct context of cit types
<s:ruleÂ context="tei:cit[@type = 'translationEquivalent']"> <s:assertÂ test="parent::tei:sense">translationEquivalent: must be a direct child of a sense element</s:assert> <s:assertÂ test="child::tei:bibl|child::tei:form[not(@type)]">translationEquivalent: a bibliographic reference or a form without a type attribute must be direct children of cit type translationEquivalent.</s:assert> </s:rule> <s:ruleÂ context="tei:cit[@type = 'translation']"> <s:reportÂ test="* except (tei:quote|tei:cit|tei:bibl|tei:form)">a translation may only contain the translated text in a quote element</s:report> </s:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"
Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="quote"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="cit"Â minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="fs"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="bibl"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="note"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="usg"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="gloss"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="form"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element cit
{
   att.global.attributes,
   attribute type
   {
      "example" | "translation" | "translationEquivalent" | "etymon"
   },
   attribute subtype { "proverb" | "verbatim" | "scientificName" }?,
   ( quote | cit* | fs | bibl | note | usg | gloss | form )+
}â

2.1.17. <citedRange>

<citedRange> (cited range) defines the range of cited content, often represented by pages or other units [3.12.2.5. Scopes and Ranges in Bibliographic Citations]

    • @unit
    • @from
    • @to
Member of
model.biblPart
Contained by
core: bibl biblStruct
May contain
core: abbr cit date gloss name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

When a single page is being cited, use the from and to attributes with an identical value. When no clear endpoint is provided, the from attribute may be used without to; for example a citation such as âp. 3ffâ might be encoded <citedRange from="3">p. 3ff</citedRange>.

Example
<citedRange>pp 12â13</citedRange> <citedRangeÂ unit="page"Â from="12"Â to="13"/> <citedRangeÂ unit="volume">II</citedRange> <citedRangeÂ unit="page">12</citedRange>
Example
<bibl> Â <ptrÂ target="#mueller01"/>, <citedRangeÂ target="http://example.com/mueller3.xml#page4">vol. 3, pp. Â Â  4-5</citedRange> </bibl>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element citedRange
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.pointing.attributes,
   att.citing.attributes,
   macro.phraseSeq
}â

textstructure: div
Example
<body> Â <divÂ type="part"> Â Â <head>Fallacies of Authority</head> Â Â <p>The subject of which is Authority in various shapes, and the object, to repress all Â Â Â Â  exercise of the reasoning faculty.</p> Â Â <divÂ n="1"Â type="chapter"> Â Â Â <head>The Nature of Authority</head> Â Â Â <p>With reference to any proposed measures having for their object the greatest Â Â Â Â Â Â  happiness of the greatest number [...]</p> Â Â Â <divÂ n="1.1"Â type="section"> Â Â Â Â <head>Analysis of Authority</head> Â Â Â Â <p>What on any given occasion is the legitimate weight or influence to be attached to Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  authority [...] </p> Â Â Â </div> Â Â Â <divÂ n="1.2"Â type="section"> Â Â Â Â <head>Appeal to Authority, in What Cases Fallacious.</head> Â Â Â Â <p>Reference to authority is open to the charge of fallacy when [...] </p> Â Â Â </div> Â Â </div> Â </div> </body>
Schematronassert content of top-level divisions
<s:ruleÂ context="tei:div[@type = 'examples']"> <s:assertÂ test="every $e in * satisfies $e/self::tei:cit[@type = 'example']">div type="examples" may only contain cit type="example"</s:assert> </s:rule> <s:ruleÂ context="tei:div[@type = 'entries']"> <s:assertÂ test="every $e in * satisfies $e/self::tei:entry">div type="entries" may only contain entry elements</s:assert> </s:rule>
Schematron
<sch:reportÂ test="(ancestor::tei:l or ancestor::tei:lg) and not(ancestor::tei:floatingText)"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div, unless div is a descendant of floatingText. </sch:report>
Schematron
<sch:reportÂ test="(ancestor::tei:p or ancestor::tei:ab) and not(ancestor::tei:floatingText)"> Abstract model violation: p and ab may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div, unless div is a descendant of floatingText. </sch:report>

calendarindicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs.

StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@calendar]"> <sch:assertÂ test="string-length( normalize-space(.) ) gt 0"> @calendar indicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs, but this <sch:name/> element has no textual content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Member of
model.respLike
Contained by
core: analytic bibl monogr

dictionaries: lang

iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

A consistent format should be adopted.

Particularly where cataloguing is likely to be based on the content of the header, it is advisable to use generally recognized authority lists for the exact form of personal names.

Example
<editorÂ role="Technical_Editor">Ron Van den Branden</editor> <editorÂ role="Editor-in-Chief">John Walsh</editor> <editorÂ role="Managing_Editor">Anne Baillot</editor>

2.1.28. <entry>

<entry> (entry) contains a single structured entry in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon. [9.1. Dictionary Body and Overall Structure 9.2. The Structure of Dictionary Entries]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
Moduledictionaries
Attributes
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
  • att.global
    • xml:id
    • xml:lang
    • @n
    • @xml:base
  • att.global.rendition
    • @rend
    • @style
    • @rendition
  • att.global.linking
    • @corresp
    • @synch
    • @sameAs
    • @copyOf
    • @next
    • @prev
    • @exclude
    • @select
  • att.global.analytic
    • @ana
  • att.global.facs
    • @facs
  • att.global.change
    • @change
  • att.global.responsibility
    • @cert
    • @resp
  • att.global.source
    • @source
xml:id(identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
DatatypeID
xml:lang(language) indicates the language of the element content using a âtagâ generated according to BCP 47.
Derived fromatt.global
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
type
StatusRecommended
Suggested values include:
mainEntry
[Default]
wordFamily
homonymicEntry
relatedEntry
Member of
model.entryLike model.entryPart.top model.sensePart
Contained by
dictionaries: entry sense
textstructure: div
May contain
core: bibl biblStruct cit listBibl note ref
dictionaries: entry etym form gramGrp sense usg xr
iso-fs: fs
Note

Like all elements, <entry> inherits an xml:id attribute from the class global. No restrictions are placed on the method used to construct xml:ids; one convenient method is to use the orthographic form of the headword, appending a disambiguating number where necessary. Identification codes are sometimes included on machine-readable tapes of dictionaries for in-house use.

It is recommended to use the <sense> element even for an entry that has only one sense to group together all parts of the definition relating to the word sense since this leads to more consistent encoding across entries.

Example
<entry> Â <form> Â Â <orth>disproof</orth> Â Â <pron>dIs"pru:f</pron> Â </form> Â <gramGrp> Â Â <pos>n</pos> Â </gramGrp> Â <senseÂ n="1"> Â Â <def>facts that disprove something.</def> Â </sense> Â <senseÂ n="2"> Â Â <def>the act of disproving.</def> Â </sense> </entry>
Schematron
<s:ruleÂ context="tei:form[@source]"> <s:letÂ name="sourceIDs" Â value="tokenize(@source,' ')"/> <s:letÂ name="biblID" Â value="following-sibling::tei:listBibl/tei:bibl/@xml:id | parent::tei:form/following-sibling::tei:listBibl/tei:bibl/@xml:id | parent::tei:form/parent::tei:form/following-sibling::tei:listBibl/tei:bibl/@xml:id"/> <s:assertÂ test="every $sourceID in $sourceIDs satisfies substring-after($sourceID, '#') = $biblID">If a form element has a source attribute there must be a corresponding bibl element in listBibl ("<s:value-ofÂ select="$biblID"/>")</s:assert> </s:rule>
Schematron
<s:ruleÂ context="tei:sense[@source]"> <s:letÂ name="sourceIDs" Â value="tokenize(@source,' ')"/> <s:letÂ name="biblID" Â value="following-sibling::tei:listBibl/tei:bibl/@xml:id"/> <s:assertÂ test="every $sourceID in $sourceIDs satisfies substring-after($sourceID, '#') = $biblID">If a sense element has a source attribute there must be a corresponding bibl element in listBibl ("<s:value-ofÂ select="$biblID"/>")</s:assert> </s:rule>
Content model
<contentÂ autoPrefix="true">
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"
Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="sense"Â minOccurs="1"

    â

2.1.29. <etym>

<etym> (etymology) encloses the etymological information in a dictionary entry. [9.3.4. Etymological Information]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0

      • @style

      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select

      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs

      • @change

      • @valueDatcat
      • @targetDatcat
    • att.lexicographic.normalized
      • @norm
      • @orig
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
type
StatusRecommended
Legal values are:
borrowing
inheritance
metaphor
metonymy
compounding
grammaticalization
derivation
Member of
model.entryPart.top model.sensePart
Contained by
dictionaries: entry etym sense
May contain
core: bibl biblStruct cit gloss listBibl note quote ref term title
dictionaries: def etym gramGrp lang usg xr
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
character data
Note

May contain character data mixed with any other elements defined in the dictionary tag set.

There is no consensus on the internal structure of etymologies, or even on whether such a structure is appropriate. The <etym> element accordingly simply contains prose, within which names of languages, cited words, or parts of words, glosses, and examples will typically be prominent. The tagging of such internal objects is optional.

Example
<entry> Â <form> Â Â <orth>publish</orth> ... </form> Â <etym> Â Â <lang>ME.</lang> Â Â <mentioned>publisshen</mentioned>, Â <lang>F.</lang> Â Â <mentioned>publier</mentioned>, <lang>L.</lang> Â Â <mentioned>publicare, Â Â Â Â  publicatum</mentioned>. <xr>See <ref>public</ref>; cf. 2d <ref>-ish</ref>.</xr> Â </etym> </entry> (From: Webster's Second International)
Example
<entry> Â <form> Â Â <orth>Handschuh</orth> ... </form> Â <etymÂ type="compounding"> Â Â <oRef>Hand</oRef> (<pRefÂ notation="ipa">Ëhant</pRef>): <gloss>hand</gloss>, Â <etymÂ type="metaphor"> Â Â Â <oRef>Schuh</oRef> (<pRefÂ notation="ipa">ÊuË</pRef>): <gloss>shoe</gloss> Â Â </etym> Â </etym> </entry>
Content model
<contentÂ autoPrefix="true">
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"

Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.gLike"Â minOccurs="1"

Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="gramGrp"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="lbl"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="usg"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="xr"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration

   att.global.attributes,

   attribute type
   {
      "borrowing"
    |Â "inheritance"
    |Â "metaphor"
    |Â "metonymy"
    |Â "compounding"
    |Â "grammaticalization"
    |Â "derivation"

   (
      text
    |Â model.gLike

    |Â xr

}â

2.1.30. <extent>

ExampleThe <measure> element may be used to supply normalized or machine tractable versions of the size or sizes concerned.
<extent> Â <measureÂ unit="MiB"Â quantity="4.2">About four megabytes</measure> Â <measureÂ unit="pages"Â quantity="245">245 pages of source Â Â  material</measure> </extent>

2.1.31. <f>

<f> (feature) represents a feature value specification, that is, the association of a name with a value of any of several different types. [Â«#FSBIÂ»]
Moduleiso-fs

      • @prev

      • @facs

      • @cert
      • @resp

  • att.datcat
    • @datcat
    • @valueDatcat
    • @targetDatcat
namea single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name), providing a name for the feature.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.name
fVal(feature value) references any element which can be used to represent the value of a feature.
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.pointer
Note

If this attribute is supplied as well as content, the value referenced is to be unified with that contained.

Contained by
iso-fs: fs
May contain
iso-fs: symbol
character data
Note

The content of <f> may be textual, with the assumption that the data type of the feature value is determined by the schemaâthis is the approach used in many language-technology-oriented projects and recommendations.

Example
<fÂ name="gender"> Â <symbolÂ value="feminine"/> </f>
Example
<fs> Â <fÂ name="voice">active</f> Â <fÂ name="tense">SimPre</f> </fs>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.featureVal"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration

   att.datcat.attributes,

   attribute fVal { text }?,

2.1.32. <fileDesc>

<fileDesc> (file description) contains a full bibliographic description of an electronic file. [2.2. The File Description 2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
Moduleheader
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
Contained by
header: teiHeader
May contain
header: editionStmt extent notesStmt publicationStmt seriesStmt sourceDesc titleStmt
Note

The major source of information for those seeking to create a catalogue entry or bibliographic citation for an electronic file. As such, it provides a title and statements of responsibility together with details of the publication or distribution of the file, of any series to which it belongs, and detailed bibliographic notes for matters not addressed elsewhere in the header. It also contains a full bibliographic description for the source or sources from which the electronic text was derived.

Example
<fileDesc> Â <titleStmt> Â Â <title>The shortest possible TEI document</title> Â </titleStmt> Â <publicationStmt> Â Â <p>Distributed as part of TEI P5</p> Â </publicationStmt> Â <sourceDesc> Â Â <p>No print source exists: this is an original digital text</p> Â </sourceDesc> </fileDesc>
Content model
<contentÂ autoPrefix="true">
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="titleStmt"
Â Â Â Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="editionStmt"
Â Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="extent"Â minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="publicationStmt"
Â Â Â Â minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="seriesStmt"
Â Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="notesStmt"
Â Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â </sequence>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="sourceDesc"
Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â </sequence>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration

   (
      (
         titleStmt,

      sourceDesc*
   )
}â

      • @norm

type
StatusOptional
Legal values are:
lemma
the headword of a lemma entry
inflected
inflected form
variant
A variant form of the lemma or inflected forms. The more frequent variant should precede less frequent ones.
subtype
StatusOptional
Legal values are:
compound
Used for multi-word units
Member of

(from TLFi)
Schematronassert content of correct context of @type values
<s:ruleÂ context="tei:form[@type = 'variant']"> <s:assertÂ test="parent::tei:form[@type = ('lemma', 'inflected')]">a variant must be a direct child of the main form (type = "lemma" or "inflected").</s:assert> </s:rule> <s:ruleÂ context="tei:form[@type = ('lemma', 'inflected')]"> <s:assertÂ test="parent::tei:entry">a headword must be a direct child of an entry element. </s:assert> </s:rule> <s:ruleÂ context="tei:form[@subtype='compound']"> <s:assertÂ test="@type='lemma'">The subtype "compound" must be accompanied by the type attribute "lemma".</s:assert> </s:rule>
Content model

Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"

Â </alternate>

    â

      • @source
  • att.typed
    • @type
    • @subtype
  • att.placement
    • @place
  • att.written
    • @hand
Member of
model.headLike
Contained by
core: list listBibl
textstructure: div
May contain
core: abbr bibl biblStruct cit date gloss list listBibl name note quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

The <head> element is used for headings at all levels; software which treats (e.g.) chapter headings, section headings, and list titles differently must determine the proper processing of a <head> element based on its structural position. A <head> occurring as the first element of a list is the title of that list; one occurring as the first element of a <div1> is the title of that chapter or section.

ExampleThe most common use for the <head> element is to mark the headings of sections. In older writings, the headings or incipits may be rather longer than usual in modern works. If a section has an explicit ending as well as a heading, it should be marked as a <trailer>, as in this example:
<div1Â n="I"Â type="book"> Â <head>In the name of Christ here begins the first book of the ecclesiastical history of Â Â  Georgius Florentinus, known as Gregory, Bishop of Tours.</head> Â <div2Â type="section"> Â Â <head>In the name of Christ here begins Book I of the history.</head> Â Â <p>Proposing as I do ...</p> Â Â <p>From the Passion of our Lord until the death of Saint Martin four hundred and twelve Â Â Â Â  years passed.</p> Â Â <trailer>Here ends the first Book, which covers five thousand, five hundred and ninety-six Â Â Â Â  years from the beginning of the world down to the death of Saint Martin.</trailer> Â </div2> </div1>
ExampleWhen headings are not inline with the running text (see e.g. the heading "Secunda conclusio") they might however be encoded as if. The actual placement in the source document can be captured with the place attribute.
<divÂ type="subsection"> Â <headÂ place="margin">Secunda conclusio</head> Â <p> Â Â <lbÂ n="1251"/> Â Â <hiÂ rend="large">Potencia: habitus: et actus: recipiunt speciem ab obiectis<supplied>.</supplied> Â Â </hi> Â Â <lbÂ n="1252"/>Probatur sic. Omne importans necessariam habitudinem ad proprium Â Â  [...] Â </p> </div>
ExampleThe <head> element is also used to mark headings of other units, such as lists:
With a few exceptions, connectives are equally useful in all kinds of discourse: description, narration, exposition, argument. <listÂ rend="bulleted"> Â <head>Connectives</head> Â <item>above</item> Â <item>accordingly</item> Â <item>across from</item> Â <item>adjacent to</item> Â <item>again</item> Â <item> <!-- ... --> Â </item> </list>
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="lg"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.gLike"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.phrase"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.inter"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.lLike"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.global"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element head
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.typed.attributes,
   att.placement.attributes,
   att.written.attributes,
   (
      text
    |Â lg
    |Â model.gLike
    |Â model.phrase
    |Â model.inter
    |Â model.lLike
    |Â model.global
   )*
}â

2.1.40. <idno>

<idno> (identifier) supplies any form of identifier used to identify some object, such as a bibliographic item, a person, a title, an organization, etc. in a standardized way. [13.3.1. Basic Principles 2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc. 2.2.5. The Series Statement 3.12.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information]
Moduleheader
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
  • att.datable
    • @period
    • att.datable.w3c
      • @when
      • @notBefore
      • @notAfter
      • @from
      • @to
    • att.datable.iso
      • @when-iso
      • @notBefore-iso
      • @notAfter-iso
      • @from-iso
      • @to-iso
    • att.datable.custom
      • @when-custom
      • @notBefore-custom
      • @notAfter-custom
      • @from-custom
      • @to-custom
      • @datingPoint
      • @datingMethod
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
typecategorizes the identifier, for example as an ISBN, Social Security number, etc.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
ISBN
International Standard Book Number: a 13- or (if assigned prior to 2007) 10-digit identifying number assigned by the publishing industry to a published book or similar item, registered with the International ISBN Agency.
ISSN
International Standard Serial Number: an eight-digit number to uniquely identify a serial publication.
DOI
Digital Object Identifier: a unique string of letters and numbers assigned to an electronic document.
URI
Uniform Resource Identifier: a string of characters to uniquely identify a resource, following the syntax of RFC 3986.
VIAF
A data number in the Virtual Internet Authority File assigned to link different names in catalogs around the world for the same entity.
ESTC
English Short-Title Catalogue number: an identifying number assigned to a document in English printed in the British Isles or North America before 1801.
OCLC
OCLC control number (record number) for the union catalog record in WorldCat, a union catalog for member libraries in the Online Computer Library Center global cooperative.
calendarindicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs.
Deprecatedwill be removed on 2024-11-11
StatusOptional
Datatype1ââ occurrences ofÂ teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:*[@calendar]"> <sch:assertÂ test="string-length( normalize-space(.) ) gt 0"> @calendar indicates one or more systems or calendars to which the date represented by the content of this element belongs, but this <sch:name/> element has no textual content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Member of
model.nameLike
Contained by
core: abbr analytic author bibl biblScope citedRange date editor gloss head item monogr name note p pubPlace publisher quote resp term
header: authority change distributor edition extent idno licence principal publicationStmt rendition seriesStmt tagUsage
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
May contain
header: idno
character data
Note

<idno> should be used for labels which identify an object or concept in a formal cataloguing system such as a database or an RDF store, or in a distributed system such as the World Wide Web. Some suggested values for type on <idno> are ISBN, ISSN, DOI, and URI.

Example
<idnoÂ type="ISBN">978-1-906964-22-1</idno> <idnoÂ type="ISSN">0143-3385</idno> <idnoÂ type="DOI">10.1000/123</idno> <idnoÂ type="URI">http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/185922478</idno> <idnoÂ type="URI">http://authority.nzetc.org/463/</idno> <idnoÂ type="LT">Thomason Tract E.537(17)</idno> <idnoÂ type="Wing">C695</idno> <idnoÂ type="oldCat"> Â <gÂ ref="#sym"/>345 </idno>
In the last case, the identifier includes a non-Unicode character which is defined elsewhere by means of a <glyph> or <char> element referenced here as #sym.
Content model
<content>
Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â <textNode/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.gLike"/>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>
Â </alternate>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element idno
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.sortable.attributes,
   att.datable.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type
   {
      "ISBN" | "ISSN" | "DOI" | "URI" | "VIAF" | "ESTC" | "OCLC"
   }?,
   attribute calendar { list { + } }?,
   ( text | model.gLike | idno )*
}â

2.1.43. <item>

<item> (item) contains one component of a list. [3.8. Lists 2.6. The Revision Description]
Modulecore
Attributes

    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base

      • @rend
      • @style

    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch

      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
Contained by
core: list
May contain
core: abbr bibl biblStruct cit date gloss list listBibl name note p quote ref term title
dictionaries: lang
header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

May contain simple prose or a sequence of chunks.

Whatever string of characters is used to label a list item in the copy text may be used as the value of the global n attribute, but it is not required that numbering be recorded explicitly. In ordered lists, the n attribute on the <item> element is by definition synonymous with the use of the <label> element to record the enumerator of the list item. In glossary lists, however, the term being defined should be given with the <label> element, not n.

Example
<listÂ rend="numbered"> Â <head>Here begin the chapter headings of Book IV</head> Â <itemÂ n="4.1">The death of Queen Clotild.</item> Â <itemÂ n="4.2">How King Lothar wanted to appropriate one third of the Church revenues.</item> Â <itemÂ n="4.3">The wives and children of Lothar.</item> Â <itemÂ n="4.4">The Counts of the Bretons.</item> Â <itemÂ n="4.5">Saint Gall the Bishop.</item> Â <itemÂ n="4.6">The priest Cato.</item> Â <item> ...</item> </list>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element item
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.sortable.attributes,
   macro.specialPara
}â

2.1.46. <language>

<language> (language) characterizes a single language or sublanguage used within a text. [2.4.2. Language Usage]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
Moduleheader
Attributes
role
StatusRequired
Legal values are:
objectLanguage
Object language is the "language being described." (ISO 16642:2017)
workingLanguage
Working language is the "language used to describe objects." (ISO 16642:2017)
sourceLanguage
Source language is the language of the content to be translated. (ISO 17100:215)
targetLanguage
Target language is the language of the content into which source language content is translated. (ISO 17100:215)
ident(identifier) Supplies a language code constructed as defined in BCP 47 which is used to identify the language documented by this element, and which may be referenced by the global xml:lang attribute.
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.language
usagespecifies the approximate percentage of the text which uses this language.
StatusOptional
DatatypenonNegativeInteger
Contained by
header: langUsage
May containCharacter data only
Note

In a monolingual dictionary, where the object language and the working language are the same, one should list each as a separate <language> element with a specific role attribute. A human-readable, informal prose characterization should be supplied as content for the element. When the human-readable name(s) of languages are provided in multiple languages, the attribute xml:lang should be used to indicate what language is used to name the given object or working language.

A bilingual dictionary could be documented as having two object languages. In those cases, however, it is recommended -- and more precise -- to describe each object language as either a source language or a target language.

Example
<langUsage> Â <languageÂ ident="ru"Â role="objectLanguage" Â Â xml:lang="ru">Ð ÑÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð»Ð¸ÑÐµÑÐ°ÑÑÑÐ½ÑÐ¹ ÑÐ·ÑÐº XIX Ð²ÐµÐºÐ°</language> Â <languageÂ ident="ru" Â Â role="workingLanguage"Â xml:lang="ru">Ð¡Ð¾Ð²ÑÐµÐ¼ÐµÐ½Ð½ÑÐ¹ ÑÑÑÑÐºÐ¸Ð¹ ÑÐ·ÑÐº</language> Â <languageÂ ident="ru"Â role="objectLanguage" Â Â xml:lang="en">19th-century literary Russian</language> Â <languageÂ ident="ru" Â Â role="workingLanguage"Â xml:lang="en">Modern Russian</language> </langUsage>
Example
<langUsage> Â <languageÂ ident="chu" Â Â role="sourceLanguage">Old Church Slavic</language> Â <languageÂ ident="la"Â role="targetLanguage">Latin</language> Â <languageÂ ident="grc" Â Â role="targetLanguage">(Premodern) Greek</language> </langUsage>
Content model
<contentÂ autoPrefix="true">
Â <textNode/>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element language
{
   attribute role
   {
      "objectLanguage"
    |Â "workingLanguage"
    |Â "sourceLanguage"
    |Â "targetLanguage"
   },
   attribute ident { text },
   attribute usage { text }?,
   text
}â

model.availabilityPart
Contained by
header: availability
May contain
core: abbr bibl biblStruct cit date gloss list listBibl name note p quote ref term title

header: idno
iso-fs: fs
linking: seg
namesdates: affiliation forename orgName persName placeName surname
character data
Note

A <licence> element should be supplied for each licence agreement applicable to the text in question. The target attribute may be used to reference a full version of the licence. The when, notBefore, notAfter, from or to attributes may be used in combination to indicate the date or dates of applicability of the licence.

Example
<licenceÂ target="http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-NZETC-Help.html#licensing"> Licence: Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 New Zealand Licence </licence>
Example
<availability> Â <licenceÂ target="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/" Â Â notBefore="2013-01-01"> Â Â <p>The Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0) Licence Â Â Â Â  applies to this document.</p> Â Â <p>The licence was added on January 1, 2013.</p> Â </licence> </availability>
Content model
<content>
Â <macroRefÂ key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
    â

      • @source
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
type(type) describes the nature of the items in the list.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
gloss
(gloss) each list item glosses some term or concept, which is given by a <label> element preceding the list item.
index
(index) each list item is an entry in an index such as the alphabetical topical index at the back of a print volume.
instructions
(instructions) each list item is a step in a sequence of instructions, as in a recipe.
litany
(litany) each list item is one of a sequence of petitions, supplications or invocations, typically in a religious ritual.
syllogism
(syllogism) each list item is part of an argument consisting of two or more propositions and a final conclusion derived from them.
Note

Previous versions of these Guidelines recommended the use of type on <list> to encode the rendering or appearance of a list (whether it was bulleted, numbered, etc.). The current recommendation is to use the rend or style attributes for these aspects of a list, while using type for the more appropriate task of characterizing the nature of the content of a list.

The formal syntax of the element declarations allows <label> tags to be omitted from lists tagged <list type="gloss">; this is however a semantic error.

Member of
model.listLike
Contained by
core: head item note p quote
header: change licence rendition revisionDesc tagUsage
textstructure: div
May contain
core: head item
Note

May contain an optional heading followed by a series of items, or a series of label and item pairs, the latter being optionally preceded by one or two specialized headings.

Example
<listÂ rend="numbered"> Â <item>a butcher</item> Â <item>a baker</item> Â <item>a candlestick maker, with Â <listÂ rend="bulleted"> Â Â Â <item>rings on his fingers</item> Â Â Â <item>bells on his toes</item> Â Â </list> Â </item> </list>
Example
<listÂ type="syllogism"Â rend="bulleted"> Â <item>All Cretans are liars.</item> Â <item>Epimenides is a Cretan.</item> Â <item>ERGO Epimenides is a liar.</item> </list>
Example
<listÂ type="litany"Â rend="simple"> Â <item>God save us from drought.</item> Â <item>God save us from pestilence.</item> Â <item>God save us from wickedness in high places.</item> Â <item>Praise be to God.</item> </list>
ExampleThe following example treats the short numbered clauses of Anglo-Saxon legal codes as lists of items. The text is from an ordinance of King Athelstan (924â939):
<div1Â type="section"> Â <head>Athelstan's Ordinance</head> Â <listÂ rend="numbered"> Â Â <itemÂ n="1">Concerning thieves. First, that no thief is to be spared who is caught with Â Â Â Â  the stolen goods, [if he is] over twelve years and [if the value of the goods is] over Â Â Â Â  eightpence. Â Â <listÂ rend="numbered"> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="1.1">And if anyone does spare one, he is to pay for the thief with his Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  wergild â and the thief is to be no nearer a settlement on that account â or to Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  clear himself by an oath of that amount.</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="1.2">If, however, he [the thief] wishes to defend himself or to escape, he is Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  not to be spared [whether younger or older than twelve].</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="1.3">If a thief is put into prison, he is to be in prison 40 days, and he may Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  then be redeemed with 120 shillings; and the kindred are to stand surety for him Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  that he will desist for ever.</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="1.4">And if he steals after that, they are to pay for him with his wergild, Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  or to bring him back there.</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="1.5">And if he steals after that, they are to pay for him with his wergild, Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  whether to the king or to him to whom it rightly belongs; and everyone of those who Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  supported him is to pay 120 shillings to the king as a fine.</item> Â Â Â </list> Â Â </item> Â Â <itemÂ n="2">Concerning lordless men. And we pronounced about these lordless men, from whom Â Â Â Â  no justice can be obtained, that one should order their kindred to fetch back such a Â Â Â Â  person to justice and to find him a lord in public meeting. Â Â <listÂ rend="numbered"> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="2.1">And if they then will not, or cannot, produce him on that appointed day, Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  he is then to be a fugitive afterwards, and he who encounters him is to strike him Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  down as a thief.</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="2.2">And he who harbours him after that, is to pay for him with his wergild Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  or to clear himself by an oath of that amount.</item> Â Â Â </list> Â Â </item> Â Â <itemÂ n="3">Concerning the refusal of justice. The lord who refuses justice and upholds Â Â Â Â  his guilty man, so that the king is appealed to, is to repay the value of the goods and Â Â Â Â  120 shillings to the king; and he who appeals to the king before he demands justice as Â Â Â Â  often as he ought, is to pay the same fine as the other would have done, if he had Â Â Â Â  refused him justice. Â Â <listÂ rend="numbered"> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="3.1">And the lord who is an accessory to a theft by his slave, and it becomes Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  known about him, is to forfeit the slave and be liable to his wergild on the first Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  occasionp if he does it more often, he is to be liable to pay all that he owns.</item> Â Â Â Â <itemÂ n="3.2">And likewise any of the king's treasurers or of our reeves, who has been Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  an accessory of thieves who have committed theft, is to liable to the same.</item> Â Â Â </list> Â Â </item> Â Â <itemÂ n="4">Concerning treachery to a lord. And we have pronounced concerning treachery to Â Â Â Â  a lord, that he [who is accused] is to forfeit his life if he cannot deny it or is Â Â Â Â  afterwards convicted at the three-fold ordeal.</item> Â </list> </div1>
Note that nested lists have been used so the tagging mirrors the structure indicated by the two-level numbering of the clauses. The clauses could have been treated as a one-level list with irregular numbering, if desired.
Example
<p>These decrees, most blessed Pope Hadrian, we propounded in the public council ... and they confirmed them in our hand in your stead with the sign of the Holy Cross, and afterwards inscribed with a careful pen on the paper of this page, affixing thus the sign of the Holy Cross. <listÂ rend="simple"> Â Â <item>I, Eanbald, by the grace of God archbishop of the holy church of York, have Â Â Â Â  subscribed to the pious and catholic validity of this document with the sign of the Holy Â Â Â Â  Cross.</item> Â Â <item>I, Ãlfwold, king of the people across the Humber, consenting have subscribed with Â Â Â Â  the sign of the Holy Cross.</item> Â Â <item>I, Tilberht, prelate of the church of Hexham, rejoicing have subscribed with the Â Â Â Â  sign of the Holy Cross.</item> Â Â <item>I, Higbald, bishop of the church of Lindisfarne, obeying have subscribed with the Â Â Â Â  sign of the Holy Cross.</item> Â Â <item>I, Ethelbert, bishop of Candida Casa, suppliant, have subscribed with thef sign of Â Â Â Â  the Holy Cross.</item> Â Â <item>I, Ealdwulf, bishop of the church of Mayo, have subscribed with devout will.</item> Â Â <item>I, Ãthelwine, bishop, have subscribed through delegates.</item> Â Â <item>I, Sicga, patrician, have subscribed with serene mind with the sign of the Holy Â Â Â Â  Cross.</item> Â </list> </p>
Schematron
<sch:ruleÂ context="tei:list[@type='gloss']"> <sch:assertÂ test="tei:label">The content of a "gloss" list should include a sequence of one or more pairs of a label element followed by an item element</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.divTop"
Â Â Â minOccurs="0"/>
Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="label"Â minOccurs="0"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="item"Â minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="1"/>
Â Â </sequence>
Â </sequence>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element list
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.sortable.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type
   {
      "gloss" | "index" | "instructions" | "litany" | "syllogism"
   }?,
   ( model.divTop?, ( label?, item )+ )
}â

2.1.49. <listBibl>

<listBibl> (citation list) contains a list of bibliographic citations of any kind. [3.12.1. Methods of Encoding Bibliographic References and Lists of References 2.2.7. The Source Description 15.3.2. Declarable Elements]
Namespacehttp://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0

Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base

      • @style

      • @resp

      • @source
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
  • att.declarable
    • @default
  • att.typed
    • type
    • @subtype
typecharacterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived fromatt.typed
StatusRequired
Datatypeteidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
dictionaries
corpora
literature
Member of
model.biblLike

May contain

Example
<listBibl> Â <head>Works consulted</head> Â <bibl>Blain, Clements and Grundy: Feminist Companion to Â Â  Literature in English (Yale, 1990) Â </bibl> Â <biblStruct> Â Â <analytic> Â Â Â <title>The Interesting story of the Children in the Wood</title> Â Â </analytic> Â Â <monogr> Â Â Â <title>The Penny Histories</title> Â Â Â <author>Victor E Neuberg</author> Â Â Â <imprint> Â Â Â Â <publisher>OUP</publisher> Â Â Â Â <date>1968</date> Â Â Â </imprint> Â Â </monogr> Â </biblStruct> </listBibl>

Schema Declaration
element listBibl
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.sortable.attributes,
   att.declarable.attributes,
   att.typed.attribute.subtype,
   attribute type { "dictionaries" | "corpora" | "literature" },
   (
      model.headLike*,
      desc*,
      ( model.milestoneLike | relation | listRelation )*,
      ( model.biblLike+, ( model.milestoneLike | relation | listRelation )* )+
   )
}â

2.1.50. <listChange>

<listChange> groups a number of change descriptions associated with either the creation of a source text or the revision of an encoded text. [Â«#HD6Â» Â«#PH-changesÂ»]
Moduleheader
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
  • att.sortable
    • @sortKey
  • att.typed
    • @type
    • @subtype
orderedindicates whether the ordering of its child <change> elements is to be considered significant or not
StatusOptional
Datatypeteidata.truthValue
Defaulttrue
Contained by
header: listChange revisionDesc
May contain
header: change listChange
Note

When this element appears within the <creation> element it documents the set of revision campaigns or stages identified during the evolution of the original text. When it appears within the <revisionDesc> element, it documents only changes made during the evolution of the encoded representation of that text.

Example
<revisionDesc> Â <listChange> Â Â <changeÂ when="1991-11-11"Â who="#LB"> deleted chapter 10 </change> Â Â <changeÂ when="1991-11-02"Â who="#MSM"> completed first draft </change> Â </listChange> </revisionDesc>
Example
<profileDesc> Â <creation> Â Â <listChangeÂ ordered="true"> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="CHG-1">First stage, written in ink by a writer</change> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="CHG-2">Second stage, written in Goethe's hand using pencil</change> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="CHG-3">Fixation of the revised passages and further revisions by Â Â Â Â Â Â  Goethe using ink</change> Â Â Â <changeÂ xml:id="CHG-4">Addition of another stanza in a different hand, Â Â Â Â Â Â  probably at a later stage</change> Â Â </listChange> Â </creation> </profileDesc>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="desc"Â minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="listChange"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="change"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â </sequence>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element listChange
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.sortable.attributes,
   att.typed.attributes,
   attribute ordered { text }?,
   ( desc*, ( listChange | change )+ )
}â

2.1.51. <monogr>

<monogr> (monographic level) contains bibliographic elements describing an item (e.g. a book or journal) published as an independent item (i.e. as a separate physical object). [3.12.2.1. Analytic, Monographic, and Series Levels]
Modulecore
Attributes
  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source
      • @source
Contained by
core: biblStruct
May contain
core: author biblScope editor imprint note ref respStmt title
header: authority availability edition extent idno
Note

May contain specialized bibliographic elements, in a prescribed order.

The <monogr> element may only occur only within a <biblStruct>, where its use is mandatory for the description of a monographic-level bibliographic item.

Example
<biblStruct> Â <analytic> Â Â <author>Chesnutt, David</author> Â Â <title>Historical Editions in the States</title> Â </analytic> Â <monogr> Â Â <titleÂ level="j">Computers and the Humanities</title> Â Â <imprint> Â Â Â <dateÂ when="1991-12">(December, 1991):</date> Â Â </imprint> Â Â <biblScope>25.6</biblScope> Â Â <biblScopeÂ unit="page"Â from="377"Â to="380">377â380</biblScope> Â </monogr> </biblStruct>
Example
<biblStructÂ type="book"> Â <monogr> Â Â <author> Â Â Â <persName> Â Â Â Â <forename>Leo Joachim</forename> Â Â Â Â <surname>Frachtenberg</surname> Â Â Â </persName> Â Â </author> Â Â <titleÂ type="main"Â level="m">Lower Umpqua Texts</title> Â Â <imprint> Â Â Â <pubPlace>New York</pubPlace> Â Â Â <publisher>Columbia University Press</publisher> Â Â Â <date>1914</date> Â Â </imprint> Â </monogr> Â <series> Â Â <titleÂ type="main"Â level="s">Columbia University Contributions to Â Â Â Â  Anthropology</title> Â Â <biblScopeÂ unit="volume">4</biblScope> Â </series> </biblStruct>
Content model
<content>
Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="author"/>
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="editor"/>

Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="respStmt"/>
Â Â Â Â </alternate>
Â Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">

Â Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"

Â Â Â Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.ptrLike"/>
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>

Â Â Â Â </alternate>
Â Â Â </sequence>
Â Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="1"

Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="author"/>

Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="meeting"/>
Â Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="respStmt"/>
Â Â Â Â </alternate>
Â Â Â </sequence>
Â Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="1"Â maxOccurs="1">
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="authority"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>
Â Â Â </sequence>
Â Â </alternate>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="availability"
Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.noteLike"
Â Â Â minOccurs="0"Â maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
Â Â <sequenceÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="edition"/>
Â Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="idno"/>
Â Â Â Â <classRefÂ key="model.ptrLike"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="editor"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="sponsor"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="funder"/>
Â Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="respStmt"/>
Â Â Â </alternate>
Â Â </sequence>
Â Â <elementRefÂ key="imprint"/>
Â Â <alternateÂ minOccurs="0"
Â Â Â maxOccurs="unbounded">
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="imprint"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="extent"/>
Â Â Â <elementRefÂ key="biblScope"/>
Â Â </alternate>
Â </sequence>
</content>
    â
Schema Declaration
element monogr
{
   att.global.attributes,
   (
      (
         (
            ( author | editor | meeting | respStmt ),
            ( author | editor | meeting | respStmt )*,
            title+,
            ( model.ptrLike | idno | textLang | editor | respStmt )*
         )
       |Â (
            ( title | model.ptrLike | idno )+,
            ( textLang | author | editor | meeting | respStmt )*
         )
       |Â ( authority, idno )
      )?,
      availability*,
      model.noteLike*,
      (
         edition,
         ( idno | model.ptrLike | editor | sponsor | funder | respStmt )*
      )*,
      imprint,
      ( imprint | extent | biblScope )*
   )
}â

2.1.52. <name>

<name> (name, proper noun) contains a proper noun or noun phrase. [3.6.1. Referring Strings]
Modulecore

  • att.global
    • @xml:id
    • @n
    • @xml:lang
    • @xml:base
    • att.global.rendition
      • @rend
      • @style
      • @rendition
    • att.global.linking
      • @corresp
      • @synch
      • @sameAs
      • @copyOf
      • @next
      • @prev
      • @exclude
      • @select
    • att.global.analytic
      • @ana
    • att.global.facs
      • @facs
    • att.global.change
      • @change
    • att.global.responsibility
      • @cert
      • @resp
    • att.global.source

character data
Note

Proper nouns referring to people, places, and organizations may be tagged instead with <persName>, <placeName>, or <orgName>, when the TEI module for names and dates is included.

Example
<nameÂ type="person">Thomas Hoccleve</name> <nameÂ type="place">Villingaholt</name> <nameÂ type="org">Vetus Latina Institut</name> <nameÂ type="person"Â ref="#HOC001">Occleve</name>
